verses.text:
Now the word of the \nd LORD\nd* came unto Jonah the son of
Amittai, saying,\f + \fr 1.1  \ft Jonah: Gr. Jonas\f*

Arise, go to Nineveh, that great city, and cry against it; for their
wickedness is come up before me.

But Jonah rose up to flee unto Tarshish from the presence of the
\nd LORD\nd*, and went down to Joppa; and he found a ship going to
Tarshish: so he paid the fare thereof, and went down into it, to
go with them unto Tarshish from the presence of the \nd LORD\nd*.

¶ But the \nd LORD\nd* sent out a great wind into the sea, and there was a
mighty tempest in the sea, so that the ship was like to be broken.\f + \fr 1.4 
\ft sent out: Heb. cast forth\f*\f + \fr 1.4  \ft was like…: Heb. thought to be
broken\f*

Then the mariners were afraid, and cried every man unto his
god, and cast forth the wares that \add were\add* in the ship into the
sea, to lighten \add it\add* of them. But Jonah was gone down into the
sides of the ship; and he lay, and was fast asleep.

So the shipmaster came to him, and said unto him, What meanest thou, O
sleeper? arise, call upon thy God, if so be that God will think upon us, that we
perish not.

And they said every one to his fellow, Come, and let us cast
lots, that we may know for whose cause this evil \add is\add* upon us. So they
cast lots, and the lot fell upon Jonah.

Then said they unto him, Tell us, we pray thee, for whose cause this
evil \add is\add* upon us; What \add is\add* thine occupation? and
whence comest thou? what \add is\add* thy country? and of what people
\add art\add* thou?

And he said unto them, I \add am\add* an Hebrew; and I fear
the \nd LORD\nd*, the God of heaven, which hath made the sea and the
dry \add land\add*.\f + \fr 1.9  \ft the \+nd LORD\+nd*: or, \+nd JEHOVAH\+nd*\f*

Then were the men exceedingly afraid, and said unto him, Why hast thou
done this? For the men knew that he fled from the presence of the
\nd LORD\nd*, because he had told them.\f + \fr 1.10  \ft exceedingly…: Heb. with great
fear\f*

¶ Then said they unto him, What shall we do unto thee, that the
sea may be calm unto us? for the sea wrought, and was tempestuous.\f + \fr 1.11 
\ft may…: Heb. may be silent from us\f*\f + \fr 1.11  \ft wrought…: or, grew more and more tempestuous: Heb.
went\f*

And he said unto them, Take me up, and cast me forth into the
sea; so shall the sea be calm unto you: for I know that for my sake
this great tempest \add is\add* upon you.

Nevertheless the men rowed hard to bring \add it\add* to the
land; but they could not: for the sea wrought, and was tempestuous against
them.\f + \fr 1.13  \ft rowed: Heb. digged\f*\f + \fr 1.13  \ft wrought…: or, grew more and more tempestuous: Heb.
went\f*

Wherefore they cried unto the 
d LORD
d*, and said, We beseech
thee, O 
d LORD
d*, we beseech thee, let us not perish for this
man’s life, and lay not upon us innocent blood: for thou, O 
d LORD
d*,
hast done as it pleased thee.

So they took up Jonah, and cast him forth into the sea: and the
sea ceased from her raging.\f + \fr 1.15  \ft ceased: Heb. stood\f*

Then the men feared the \nd LORD\nd* exceedingly, and offered
a sacrifice unto the \nd LORD\nd*, and made vows.\f + \fr 1.16  \ft offered…: Heb. sacrifice unto the
\+nd LORD\+nd*, and vowed vows\f*

¶ Now the \nd LORD\nd* had prepared a great fish to swallow
up Jonah. And Jonah was in the belly of the fish three days and three
nights.\f + \fr 1.17  \ft belly: Heb. bowels\f*

Then Jonah prayed unto the \nd LORD\nd* his God out of the
fish’s belly,

And said, I cried by reason of mine affliction unto the \nd LORD\nd*,
and he heard me; out of the belly of hell cried I, \add and\add*
thou heardest my voice.\f + \fr 2.2  \ft by…: or, out of mine affliction\f*\f + \fr 2.2 
\ft hell: or, the grave\f*

Then I said, I am cast out of thy sight; yet I will look again
toward thy holy temple.

The waters compassed me about, \add even\add* to the soul:
the depth closed me round about, the weeds were wrapped about my
head.

I went down to the bottoms of the mountains; the earth with her
bars \add was\add* about me for ever: yet hast thou brought up my
life from corruption, O \nd LORD\nd* my God.\f + \fr 2.6  \ft bottoms: Heb. cuttings
off\f*\f + \fr 2.6  \ft corruption: or, the pit\f*

When my soul fainted within me I remembered the \nd LORD\nd*:
and my prayer came in unto thee, into thine holy temple.
They that observe lying vanities forsake their own mercy.

¶ And the \nd LORD\nd* spake unto the fish, and it vomited
out Jonah upon the dry \add land\add*.

And the word of the \nd LORD\nd* came unto Jonah the second
time, saying,

Arise, go unto Nineveh, that great city, and preach unto it the
preaching that I bid thee.

So Jonah arose, and went unto Nineveh, according to the word
of the \nd LORD\nd*. Now Nineveh was an exceeding great city of three
days’ journey.\f + \fr 3.3  \ft exceeding: Heb. of God\f*

And Jonah began to enter into the city a day’s journey, and he
cried, and said, Yet forty days, and Nineveh shall be overthrown.

¶ So the people of Nineveh believed God, and proclaimed a fast,
and put on sackcloth, from the greatest of them even to the least of them.

For word came unto the king of Nineveh, and he arose from his
throne, and he laid his robe from him, and covered \add him\add*
with sackcloth, and sat in ashes.

And he caused \add it\add* to be proclaimed and published through
Nineveh by the decree of the king and his nobles, saying, Let neither
man nor beast, herd nor flock, taste any thing: let them not feed,
nor drink water:\f + \fr 3.7  \ft published: Heb. said\f*\f + \fr 3.7 
\ft nobles: Heb. great men\f*

But let man and beast be covered with sackcloth, and cry mightily
unto God: yea, let them turn every one from his evil way, and from the
violence that \add is\add* in their hands.

Who can tell \add if\add* God will turn and repent, and turn
away from his fierce anger, that we perish not?

¶ And God saw their works, that they turned from their evil
way; and God repented of the evil, that he had said that he would
do unto them; and he did \add it\add* not.
But it displeased Jonah exceedingly, and he was very angry.

And he prayed unto the \nd LORD\nd*, and said, I pray thee, O
\nd LORD\nd*, \add was\add* not this my saying, when I was yet in my
country? Therefore I fled before unto Tarshish: for I knew that thou
\add art\add* a gracious God, and merciful, slow to anger, and of
great kindness, and repentest thee of the evil.

Therefore now, O \nd LORD\nd*, take, I beseech thee, my life from me; for
\add it is\add* better for me to die than to live.

¶ Then said the \nd LORD\nd*, Doest thou well to be angry?\f + \fr 4.4 
\ft Doest…: or, Art thou greatly angry?\f*

So Jonah went out of the city, and sat on the east side of the
city, and there made him a booth, and sat under it in the shadow,
till he might see what would become of the city.

And the \nd LORD\nd* God prepared a gourd, and made \add it\add*
to come up over Jonah, that it might be a shadow over his head, to
deliver him from his grief. So Jonah was exceeding glad of the gourd.\f + \fr 4.6 
\ft gourd: or, palmcrist: Heb. Kikajon\f*\f + \fr 4.6  \ft was…: Heb. rejoiced with great
joy\f*

But God prepared a worm when the morning rose the next day,
and it smote the gourd that it withered.

And it came to pass, when the sun did arise, that God prepared
a vehement east wind; and the sun beat upon the head of Jonah, that he
fainted, and wished in himself to die, and said, \add It is\add*
better for me to die than to live.\f + \fr 4.8  \ft vehement: or,
silent\f*

And God said to Jonah, Doest thou well to be angry for the
gourd? And he said, I do well to be angry, \add even\add* unto death.\f + \fr 4.9 
\ft Doest…: or, Art thou greatly angry?\f*\f + \fr 4.9  \ft I do well…: or, I am greatly
angry\f*

Then said the \nd LORD\nd*, Thou hast had pity on the gourd,
for the which thou hast not laboured, neither madest it grow; which came up in a
night, and perished in a night:\f + \fr 4.10  \ft had pity: or, spared\f*\f + \fr 4.10 
\ft came…: Heb. was the son of the night\f*

And should not I spare Nineveh, that great city, wherein are
more than sixscore thousand persons that cannot discern between their right
hand and their left hand; and \add also\add* much cattle?
